text.p: - Talks about a deal offering "credits to the Kremlin in exchange for the expansion of NATO" seem to have some basis.
- Russia's banking circles expect a new law on taxing government securities to have a negative impact.
- Russian Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin blamed senior government officials for the non-payment crisis, giving them two weeks to come up with measures to ease the situation.
- Russia's cash-strapped army would be uncontrollable if military action were needed, a senior Defence Ministry official is quoted as saying.

- Russians are expected to believe in a new economic miracle after expenses for housing and municipal services are raised. The higher costs are part of a new programme of reforms offered by Economy Ministry.

- The Federation Council upper house of Russia's parliament has denied the right of deputies of the lower house to use budget funds to buy Moscow apartments. Duma view the decision as a slap in the face.
- Former prisoners of war or hostagees from Chechnya must present a document confirming they were forced to stay on the territory to get compensation and their jobs back.
